title: Censer
text:
Reflecting the scholarly taste for antiquity, this gilded bronze censer is made in vague imitation of a bronze age ritual vessel called kuei. It is cast and carved in relief displaying a wave pattern with dragons, phoenix, and other mythological animals all accented in gilt.

The center of the base is inset with a large, rectangular cartouche containing a six-character seal-script mark which reads, "made by Chu chen-ming of Yun-chien, Sung-chiang Kiangsu." Very few bronzes with Chu's mark have survived. He evidently worked in Hu-Wen-ming's (1573-1620) workshop where he completely assimilated the master's style and then became an independent artisan producing bronze objects in scholar's taste.
description: low, wide foot with flaring body and slightly inverted wide mouth; pair of dragon-shaped handles; dragons and fantastic animals carved on body; chased floral design on foot; gilt highlights on carving
creditline: Gift of Ruth and Bruce Dayton
